item.description:
Bible Card Game is a religious variation on Go Fish. Cards are numbered 1-13, with each number representing a biblical prophets and persons. (The cards go from Adam and Eve to Paul.) There are also four suits, Churches, Stars, Stone Tablets, and Rods. Players ask others for the cards they need to complete the "Books" by asking for the name of the person pictured on the card.

The rules make note that this deck of cards is appropriate for other standard card games as well.

Another Uno Variation. The Betty Boop Vintage Edition. Comes in a special collector's tin and stars vintage Betty Boop and company.

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: On-the-Go card and rule.

name.value: The All American Trivia Board Game: Junior Edition
American Trivia Board Game Junior Edition

item.description:
Description from the Publisher's Website

Have you ever wanted to just play games rather than study for your history or geography test? Well now you can do both at the same time!

Outset Media is proud to introduce the Junior Edition of the best-selling All American Trivia Board Game. Designed specifically for younger players, the Junior Edition allows youth to have a blast, challenging each other’s knowledge on 100% American content in a fun, social atmosphere.

The game is easy to learn, with three categories -- geography, history, and general. It’s a race around the game board. With over 1,080 questions, the game includes questions such as "Who is famous for his ‘I have a dream’ speech?" And "What is the largest state in America?"

item.description: Neworld is an economic game where the object is to make as much money as possible, by buying and selling stocks, currency and raw materials. The value of the commodities changes with each turn so the best time for buying and selling varies all the time. The game ends either after a pre-determined time has elapsed or when one player has brought the others to their knees.

A role and move game designed as an educational tool to 'foster pride, dignity and self awareness'.

A large colorful gameboard is included with 4 cube playing pieces, 11 Red cards and 17 Blue cards. Instructions are printed on inside of box cover.

"The Black Experience" is designed to emphasize some of the many contributions that Black people have made in Medicine, Technology, Literature, Government, Sports, Entertainment and other fields.

Tigers to the Front! is a module set on the Eastern Front of World War II between June 23rd and June 28th The scenarios primarily feature the German 121st infantry division and the 502nd Heavy Panzer Battalion as they defend against attacks by the Russian 1st Shock Army.

Contents:
22"x34" map
10 scenarios

Tigers to the Front! is not a complete game. Ownership of Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1 from the ASL game system is required to play this module.


May 2012- Panther Line is released.

This update to Tigers to the Front includes new color die-cut counters, two additional scenarios, new art, the new layout, all errata input and the usual balance tweaks. The action brings you right into the turrets of the Pzkw VI Tigers of the 502 Schwere Panzer Abteilung, 94th Grenadier Regiment, and 1st Shock Army and other hard-fighting combat elements. You receive all the vehicles used in the scenarios in camo-colored editions, plus a new set of German MMC/SMC counters in new poses and uniforms—to provide a unique Eastern Front gaming experience. 
The set includes 12 scenarios, a Special Rules booklet, two sheet of color die-cut counters (296 counters in all), and an historical map of the Panther Line positions. Ownership of Beyond ValorTM is required but owners of the recent CH Berlin release "Final Days" will have all of the Gun and infantry counters needed to play the scenarios in a 'CH only' counter presentation using the counters provided in ASLComp Panther Line.

name.value: The Wild West: The Range Wars of 19th Century America

item.description:
The Wild West (TWW) is a game in which each player is a cattle rancher in the American West (mid 19th century), each of whom is trying to extend his “spread” to get access to the resources he needs as well as increasing his worth. TWW can be played by from two to five players. The game plays somewhat differently based on the number of players involved, but it should take about three hours.

Rustling, Poker Games, Gunfights and the Railroad are all contained in this game of the American West.

One out of 30 pictures from art history is hidden under 12 wooden tiles and revealed part by part. After any "revelation" the players have to answer one of 14 questions from a questionnaire and talk about the part that can be seen plus answering the question. Each answer that sounds correct to the other players, gets a point (chip).

Since any player is allowed to answer each question only once, it gets harder in the successing game to reply properly.

After the picture is completely revealed, the answers are re-checked in the rulebook, and each correct answer gets more points.

More a game for funny talk and make it believable, than for real art education. But the details you can explore in the process of revealing the pictures and discuss the answers, are illuminative fun.

Stafaspilið (The Game of Letters) is a lot like Scrabble but without a board. Players get 8 tiles with a letter on each and the goal is to get rid of all the tiles from the hand. Each tile has a value which is used when a word is formed.

Each word that can be read from the new one is counted. For example if a player puts down 'house' he gets points for both 'house' and 'use'. The player who finishes first gets the points from the tiles in the hands of the other players.

Undir sólinni (Beneath the sun) is a trivia game with 4000 questions about everything beneath the sun. The questions are in four categories (Icelandic history, the Icelandic language and literature, childrens' questions and common questions) and each category has two difficulty levels (easy and hard). The players decide at the start what category and difficulty they will answer and then whether to use a six-sided die or twelve-sided die. The object is to travel around the four-part track, gathering stars for correctly answered questions which can be used to advance more quickly.

In Kvikmyndaspilið (The Movie Game), players form teams (three in each team is best although two player teams can work) and act out scenes from a movie to make their team members guess which movie it is. The opposite team usually chooses the movie and one player of the team tries to act out the scene in less than two minutes. If the team members guess correctly, they can roll the dice and move along the track. Those who are deemed to act exceptionally well get The Oscar statue which gives +1 on a die roll.
The players must get at least one wagon from an Eastern Town to West City safely, avoiding Indians and other dangers on the trail.

From the publisher: "On this superfun lake you'll catch fishes of all sizes. The largeer fishes worth 3 or 5 points each and the smaller ones 1 or 2 points There are also the fishbones that are worthless, they are there just to hinder your fishing. So you'll need a bit of luck to catch the better fishes before the other player. Who get more points at the end is the winner!"

This is a cute little game for the small kids (ages 4 to 8), where two players race to catch the most fish but also the bigger fishes. When all the fishes are caught, players add their points, who got the most wins, simple as that!

From the back of the box:

"Trial '97 brings together facets of the riddle of the future of Hong Kong which now confronts the 6 million inhabitants who are the pawns in this game of intrigue. Invite your friends to roll the dice and play the future of Hong Kong. Politics, Power, Money and Technique will challenge your every move to Trial 1997!"

Published in 1987, when the future of Hong Kong was uncertain, this is a roll and take an action game where players try to get as much money out of Hong Kong as possible before the final handover.

item.description: This is a simple roll and move game where the players try to get from the starting point to the end, with 90 numbered points on the route, 14 of them with special rules. 13 of those rules have something to do with one of the Icelandic Yule Lads (similar to Santa Claus).

Galaxy was first published as "game in the magazine" in the AHA-Zeitung #87/2, the zine of several joint Swiss Playing Clubs. In winter 1987, Editoy published it as a real game.

The huge board shows a universe with 6 planets, 36 space stations and about 50 meteorites. The planets are connected with thick planet routes, the space stations with thinner space station routes, and the meteorites with dotted meteorite routes. Movement is done with movement tickets, which are won by throwing a die.

Each planet is the home planet of a player's space ship, thus up to 6 people can play a game.

Object of the game is to visit all 6 space station of the own colour and return to the home planet first. This can be rather difficult, because 18 "magnetic fields" block the same number of routes. Besides moving his space ship during his turn, a player takes any magnetic field and places it on a new route.

Club 3 was first published as game in the magazine in "WIN" #45, the zine of the "Spielekreis Wien" in Austria. It was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" two months later.

The game is somehow a derivate of Poker - with less cards, less combinations, but more interactions between the players.

The card deck consists of only 24 cards; 4 suits of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6.

There are only 3 combinations with a little strange names: 
- Wortklauberei (logomachy): 2 cards with numbers directly adjacent each other
- Redeschwall (flood of words): 2 cards with the same numbers
- Phasendreschen (to rant): 2 cards, 1 showing an "1", the other a "6"

Each round is played with 4 cards per player; there is no possibility to exchange any of them. The first player, who thinks he has a good hand, starts the game by playing 1 card and any number of chips on it. This bet can be attacked by any player. The attacker can choose, if he wants to attack alone or with the help of another player. That means, that the original better can be forced to play against 2 players! An important restriction is, that a maximum of 3 cards can be used on each side, which would form 1 or 2 combinations.

The game ends after a preassigned time and the player with the most chips is the winner.

High Noon was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #87/4.

The board consists of 12 spaces, where 12 subsequent races are carried out.

Each of the 4 players has 1 token and a set of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6. These cards are used to move the tokens. Every turn, all players play one of their cards simultaneously. Passing other tokens is possible at the cost of 2 movement points, but landing on occupied fields is forbidden; such a move would forfeit.

While the first race starts with all tokens off the board, the following 11 races leave all tokens where they have been at the end of the previous race. But the finishing line will be shifted by 7 fields.

Up to 12 points can be won per race and the winner is the player with the most points after all 12 races.

Godzilla was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #88/1.

The game is played on a 10x10 board. One player plays with Gozilla, the other one plays with 6 people/tokens from Tokyo. Each of the 6 Tokyo tokens has a different colour and wears an imaginary weapon of the same colour.

Before the game begins, the Tokyo player places 40 houses, 10 monster-immune houses and his 6 tokens on the board. Gozilla waits outside the board.

The Gozilla player is dealt 6 cards showing the 6 colours of the weapons. He is immune against 4 of the 6 weapons and to document which ones, he secretly keeps 4 of the 6 cards.

During a turn, the Tokyo player must move 3 of his tokens by 1 space, the Gozilla player moves Gozilla by 2 spaces. Gozilla can destroy houses, but not Tokyo tokens or monster-immune houses.

The Tokyo player wins, if he can move one of his 2 tokens with a "sharp" weapon on the space where Gozilla is. Gozilla wins, if he can destroy 15 houses before he is killed.

Burza Zimowa 1942 (Winter Storm 1942) : the Germans hoped to relieve the 6th Army encircled in Stalingrad by breaking through the Russian lines. The operation was a failure since the Soviet HQ sent strong reinforcements to the area and stopped the German advance and thus the 6th Army was doomed.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions (Germans) or regiments (Russians), one hex represents 1500m, one turn represents 12 hours.

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

A wargame about the Battle of the Kasserine Pass. The battle was a victory of the Italo-German forces under Erwin Rommel over unexperienced American forces led by Lloyd Fredendall who was relieved after the battle.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions, one hex represents 1000m, one turn represents 8 hours.

Szczury Pustyni (Desert Rats) depicts several battles fought in Libya between 1940 and 1942. Counters and scenarios are for Operation Compass (British victory over the Italians), Rommel's first offensive (pushing the British back to Egypt), Operation Battleaxe (first and failed attempt by the Allies to relieve Tobruk), Operation Crusader (successful Allied attempt to relieve Tobruk) and Battle of Gazala (Rommel's second thrust that reached Egypt).

The game uses simplified rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed to simulate medium battles of World War II with some additional rules too, dealing with specific aspects of desert warfare. Counters represent battalions, one hex represents 3000m, one turn represents one day.

item.description:
A wargame about the final phase of Russian offensive in summer 1944. After the success of operation Bagration and destruction of German Army Group Centre, the Soviets advanced quickly towards the Vistula river and Warsaw. Already exhausted from the earlier fights and 500km advance the Russians encountered strong German forces pulled from the Italian front just when they were about to cross Vistula and capture Warsaw. At the same time the Warsaw Uprising began, complicating the German situation.

The game uses the "Wielkie Bitwy II Wojny 1939-45" or "WB95" (Great Battles of World war II 1939-1945) rules designed to simulate large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents 2500m, one turn represents one day.

Description from the gamebox:

Border Castle Battles

A strategic-historical game for children above 10. This is a stop-gap game in the sense that is provides exciting passtime activity for children above ten and even adults. The point is that the game enables you to re-play four campaigns of the 16th century /they took place actually/ with a relatively high degree of faithfulness to reality. This game is not the usual simple one you play with dice, it requires brains, tactics and good strategic ideas. If there are two players, one is the commander-in-chief of the Turkish army the other one is that of the Hungarian one. They take steps on the battlefield /the table/ which is authentic both historically and geographically.
While stepping forward - in line with their strategic ideas - they fight each other, protect or storm fortresses. In case of more players the countries may be divided among them, e.g. the players can be commanders of a Northern Hungarian castle or that of a Transdanubian fortress respectively...()
We sincerely hope that this short piece of information arouse your interest in this type of game outstanding also in its design, and being the first of its kind - since historical strategic games are just about to be spread in Hungary...()

A wargame about the famous last battle of Napoleon. The goal of the French is to break the Allied line before the Prussian reinforcements arrive and turn the tide.

The game uses a very detailed system designed for dealing with battles of the Napoleonic Period. Counters represent companies (skirmishers), battalions (regular infantry), regiments (cavalry) and batteries (artillery), one hex represents 120m, one turn represents 20 minutes. At this scale Waterloo, being a large battle, needs 600 counters!

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

Related Microbadges
 Dragon fan

item.description: Players build stacks of Lego Duplo blocks to reach berries. First one to return to the start space with the required number of blocks, wins. Three ways to play using counting, addition or subtraction.

item.description: This game was inclued with Practical Wargamer magazine, Jan/Feb 1997 vol 10 no 7. It includes a separate map, rules and counters. Movement and combat are very simple, and are described as a basic outline framework for refighting the battle, with opportunities for improvements and extensions by the players.

A wargame about the "Market-Garden" operation.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions, one hex represents 2000m, one turn represents 8 hours.

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

The second edition of the game was published in "Taktyka i Strategia" magazine #9 and #10

name.value: Fem myror är fler än fyra elefanter: Lär om siffror

item.description:
A sister game of `Fem myror är fler än fyra elefanter: Lär om bokstäver´, this is a children´s game about numbers. There are seven different ways to play, representing seven difficulty levels.

Players each have their own board. A number of tiles are placed face-down on the table, a la Memory. Players roll the die to see how many tiles (1, 2 or 3) they may turn face-up. Any tiles that match the player´s board are placed on the board.

In the seven variants, players are required to match numbers with numbers (2 - 2, easy), animals with numbers (two lions - 2, slightly more advanced), and so on.

The winner is the first player to fill his/her board.

Themed on a very popular Swedish TV show for kids.

From the publisher (site: http://www.ddd-verlag.de ).

An innovative cardgame from Hanno and Wilfried Kuhn situated in Florenz - the cradle of the Renaissance. Artists such as Botticelli, Michelangelo and da Vinci worked in this city, the preacher Savonarola established a God state and Machiavelli wrote his works on the theory of power. Here the Medici prevailed and the city saw the birth of important discoverers such as Vespucci.

As the head of an influential European aristocracy you will try to lead your family to a cultural and power-political top. In the face of the historical events of this time you promote cultural achievements such as architecture and religion, financing, the sciences and naturally also the voyages of discovery. Surround yourself with the powerful ones of this time and use all your diplomacy skills to achieve a crucial advantage against your competitors. Only the player with the most influence stones will win the game ...

Box content:
- 36 historical events 
- 40 culture cards
- 27 person cards
- 5 summary cards 
- 28 influence stones (7 in each of the colors yellow, red, black and white) 
- 4 genius figures (1 in each of the colors yellow, red, black and white)
- 1 rules book

item.description:
[EN] 11 de Setembre is an introductory wargame with very simple rules, reproducing the siege and fall of the city of Barcelona on September 11th 1714, at the hands of the Spanish-French Bourbon army. The fall of Barcelona effectively ended the War of the Spanish Succession.

It contains one 50x70 cm map, a rulebook and 88 counters.


[CA] 11 de Setembre és un wargame introductori amb regles molt simples i que reprodueix el setge i caiguda de Barcelona l'11 de setembre de 1714 a mans de l'exèrcit borbònic francoespanyol. La caiguda de Barcelona posà fi a la Guerra de Successió Espanyola.

El joc conté un mapa de 50x70 cm, un llibret de regles i 88 fitxes.


[ES] 11 de Setembre es un wargame introductorio con reglas muy simples y que reproduce el asedio y caída de Barcelona el 11 de setiembre de 1714 a manos del ejército borbónico franco-español. La caída de Barcelona puso fin a la Guerra de Sucesión Española.

El juego contiene un mapa de 50x70 cm, un libro de reglas y 88 fichas.

Guessit is a fast paced game played like charades. Instead of acting, however, you give verbal and physical clues to your teammates, who are trying to guess the items you are describing before the time runs out. There are 4 categories of play - Places, People, Objects, and Actions & Activities. On your turn, you roll the dice to determine which category you get. There are 7 items on each card and you get 1 point for each item your team correctly guesses. The first team to 45 points wins.

Teams compete to guess closest to the year of a historic event, which is read out from a Question Card. Winning teams collect tokens and roll the dice to move around the board in a race to the Center.

The game includes a board, eight different characters to represent the teams playing, a sandglass timer, two dice, a scoresheet, six pencils, a novel magnetic category selection unit, question/answer cards, timecards, rules, and a mini-reference sheet.

The game is played in rounds, the first of which is similar to a round of trivial pursuit. The second round introduces timecards, which tweaks gameplay by giving teams various powers, such as stealing points. The game sequence also changes to shake things up a bit.

Very much like an exciting Trivial Pursuit, adding various new mechanics.

Released at Spiel 2007.

Eurojuego de Salamanca is a Monopoly like game played in this Spanish city. Nevertheless, they have introduced some variants that gives the game a twist for the better, such as the special commodities to buy or services contracts.

The game was distributed with El Adelanto, a local newspaper.

From the back of the box:

"Since September 27th, 2004, the Dominican Republic has a new criminal procedural law, based in an accusatory system, which replaces the one from 1844 that was inspired in the old French code based in an inquisitive model.

In order to announce the new legal frame, the Escuela Nacional de la Judicatura presents this process in a ludic educational form to the justice servers, the Policía Nacional and to the citizens in general."

link.value: Escuela Nacional de la Judicatura de la República Dominicana

name.value: The Board Game of The Golden Compass
Der goldene Kompass: Spiel zum Film

item.description:
Disambiguation: This game is for the Golden Compass movie, the game for the book is located over here.

 


Players are part of Philip Pullman’s creation, as portrayed in the motion picture: a world very much like our own, but existing in a parallel universe. The game features graphics and pictures taken from the movie. Players alternate in leading Lyra in her journey to rescue her friends, as she escapes from the Magisterium's clutches. As each turn unfolds, players collect items and clues, and help Lyra to understand the Alethiometer - the truth-measuring Golden Compass. During a turn a player uses the Alethiometer spindle: the spinning action reveals the two actions the player is allowed to choose from. A typical move involves playing or drawing Lyra cards, played in sets to collect Item tiles from the board (representing Lyra and Pan's actions and investigations) or placing Symbol tokens that will later let a player draw valuable Truth tokens (representing the interpretation of the Alethiometer). Character cards, showing the main heroes and villains of the story, can be used by players to alter the gameplay by applying their special abilities. The winner is the player that scores the most points by the end of the game.

item.description:
In Cockroach Salad players create a common salad packed with lettuce, peppers, tomatoes and cauliflower – but they won't always be saying which ingredient they're adding to the bowl!

The 128 cards – 120 vegetable cards in the four types and eight "taboo" vegetable cards, two of each type that bear cockroaches – are shuffled and divided among the players. On a turn, a player plays the top card from his deck onto the central pile of cards, naming the vegetable as he plays it, e.g., "Pepper!" – except in the following situations:

• If his vegetable matches the previously played vegetable, the player must lie.
• If his vegetable matches the claim made by the previous player (perhaps because that player lied), then the player must lie.
• If he plays a taboo card, he shouts "Cockroach!" and the next player starts a new pile next to the first one so that the taboo card remains visible.
• If his vegetable matches a visible taboo card, he must lie.

Make a mistake or stumble or hesitate too long, and a player must pick up all cards played to that point in the game. The first player to run out of cards wins!

Can be combined with Kakerlakensuppe.

item.description:
De Matrica Bellae is a set of matrix game rules for tabletop wargames by Graham D. Evans and was published as the Society of Ancients incentive game for 2005. The matrix style of play often produces an anarchic type of game and also needs an umpire, but can produce an entertaining game that is good fun and can provide a lot of value to the wargamer. DMB also includes a bonus matrix game campaign, "Londinium's Burning" - a matrix version of the Iceni revolt led by Boudicca.

(from the SOA website)

Matrix games use structured arguments rather than mathematics to determine the success or failure of actions within the game.

item.description:
Gladitorial combat using dominoes to determine the attack and defence values of the combatants. Different types of gladiator are included (retiarius, murmillo etc) with appropriate weapons and armour. A number of useful appendices about aspects of the historical background are also included, along with an additional game "Anno Domino" which is a simpler game based on similar lines.

This was a society subscription game but is also available separately.

item.description:
A fast play set of rules for fighting naval battles in the Mediterranean sea in the period 320 to 30BC. It aims to avoid book-keeping in favour of simplicity and playability. Each side plays alternately, moving all of their ships to shear off oars, grapple or ram the enemy, whilst the non-moving player can shoot back. Combat resolution is by a comparison of dice throws, with additional tactical factors. It is designed to be played with miniatures but full colour counters are provided as an alternative.

This was a Society of Ancients subscribers' game but is also available separately.

item.description:
Tock is a board game, similar to Pachisi, in which players race their four tokens around the game board from start to finish—the objective being to be the first to take all of one's tokens "home". Instead of rolling the dice to the determined movement, players are dealt cards to use for movement.

Players take turns playing cards, with the value of the card determining how far they may move a pawn. Certain cards have special possibilities (a King or an Ace may be played to get a new pawn into play, while a four moves you back instead of forward).

If more than two players a playing, they can play in teams. When you have brought all your own pawns to your safety zone, you must move your partner's pawns.

item.description:
Reproduce el combate por la población de Projorovka el 12.7.43,que tuvo lugar durante la batalla de kursk.
Wargame basico de iniciación.

Wargame basic.

Do you have what it takes to coach a Raging Champion to the final match and win?

Choose your characters and the tournament begins... Watch your Raging Champions compete one-on-one against fierce contenders in the only bracket-formatted board game available.

Use your Appeal Chips to stay out of trouble and beware the ejection card... Draw it and one of your Raging Champions is out of the tournament. As you battle and advance towards the final match, the excitement builds and coaches choose favorites - watch out because these guys are tough to beat.

Good Luck!!

For 2-5 players, Ages 5 and up.

Aboyne is a simple, fast-paced, print and play abstract game.

On their turn, a player must move one stone of their own color that is not adjacent to any enemy stone. A stone may (i) move to an adjacent empty cell or (ii) jump over a friendly stone, or a line of friendly stones, landing on the cell immediately beyond. It that cell is occupied by an enemy stone, that stone is captured. A stone cannot move into the opponent's goal cell. The winner is the player who moves a stone into their own goal cell (at the opposite end of the board) or stalemates the opponent.

				
					The Term Aboyne

The term Aboyne is taken from a humorous dictionary The deeper meaning of Liff. by Douglas Adams and John Lloyd. In there Aboyne is defined as beating an expert at a game of skill by playing so appallingly that none of his clever tactics or strategies are of any use to him.

Furthermore there exists a village in Aberdeenshire, Scotland, named Aboyne (Scots: Abyne, Scottish Gaelic: Abèidh).

item.description:
This game is a simulation of the early air bombing campaign against Iraq. Completely card driven, players draw missions and attempt to make their primary and any secondary or tertiary targets as possible by rolling dice, which can be modified by aircraft type, experimental weapons and recon missions.

Each target has a Class and a Combat Rating of 2, 3, 4, or 5.. In order to successfully destroy a target, the player must match or beat the Combat Rating listed for that target using as many dice as they wish.

This is a game based off of a map product, Master Plan: Necropolis, also published by UKG. In "Blight of the Living Dead", up to six players can act as fantasy adventurers seeking out the Lord of the Night (also a player) in the necropolis while battling undead minions and searching chests for treasure that will aid them.

It is a simple game with combat handled by opposed die rolls with variable undead reinforcement also handled by dice.


 NOTE: You MUST have the Master Plan: Necropolis product (or just make your own) to make use of this game! **

name.value: Fleet Action Imminent! General Quarters WWI Rules

item.description:
Fleet Action Imminent! General Quarters WWI Rules is a set of tabletop miniatures rules covering WWI naval combat.

It is based on the General Quarters (Third Edition) rules, tweaked to more appropriately fit the World War One timeframe instead of General Quarters' World War Two emphasis.

Miniatures scale is flexible.

Another Uno variation. Philadelphia Phillies Uno comes with 112 Custom cards featuring the Phils' 2005 line-up including Jim Thome, Bobby Abreu, Jon Lieber, Pat Burrell and more.

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: Acquisition card and rule.

name.value: Race to the Bowl with CinnaMon & Apple

item.description: This is a very basic roll-and-move game on the back of a Kellogg's Apple Jacks box. It has a Caribbean island theme (get it, CinnaMon?).

The game consists of a circular board with the numbers 1 to 12 in compartments and 15 numbered disks. The disks are tossed into he middle of the board and those that land face up can be placed in the numbered compartments as long as some simply rules are followed. Points are scored for every disk used and deducted for those face up disks that couldn't be used. The winner is the player with the most points.

The game is based on components excavated at Pompeii, although I doubt that a copy of the original rules survived the hot lava death.

Rivers and Rods is an LDS-themed variant of Chutes and Ladders. Players navigate through a map of Book of Mormon lands. When they land on the beginning of an iron rod, they can skip several places to go to the end of it and when they land on the beginning of a river they are likewise sent backward. As with many other religiously themed games, the rules specifically state that the first person to reach the end is not the winner; rather, everyone who reaches the end is the winner.

During the nineteenth century, settlers expanded rapidly across North America, from the eastern seaboard all the way to the west coast. Players' pieces represent the wagons of a bold family just arrived from the Old World and working to reach the west coast. Performance is based not on how well any one wagon does, but on how well players manage all of their wagons.

The game is played as a trick-taking game. The goal of the game is to advance wagons as quickly as possible. Every trick scores movement points. These points propel wagons across the board.

Every hand also features a hand evaluation step. Bidding a hand correctly scores extra movement points. Missing a bid scores nothing.

Blocking is also an important element of the game. By placing wagons on the game board’s prime paths, players can force each other to either go around or give up some of their precious points to push opponents forward and out of the way.

This game has been self published (at prototype quality) in an edition not to exceed 200 copies.

In this game players impersonate generals Montgommery and Rommel - leaders of 8th British Army and Afrika Korps fighting in northern Africa (1941-42).

The game uses relatively simple set of rules but it contains several mechanics concepts in: the units are represented by counters and cards; the maneuvers, terrains and leaders have appropriate cards each; and the battles are performed using cards and dice rolling.

item.description: A Monopoly variant where the properties are models of Ferrari automobiles and the players are car collectors. The winner is the player with the most money when the last Ferrari is acquired.
The Spanish French army launches assault in 1782 against fortzaleza of Gibraltar that ended in failure during the American War of Independence. Game includes one 25 x 31 inch map.
Board wargame portraying the Battle of Trafalgar on a ship-to-ship scale. Game includes one 25 x 31 inch map.

item.description:
from the website http://www.elveneargames.nl

Five of the most noble knights in the country, all want to marry the princess. There is one problem, though. The princess has been kidnapped by a dangerous dragon Fortunately, something good comes out of this situation too. This is the ultimate chance for the courageous warriors to make a good impression on the princess. That is why they go to battle to save the princess. Because only one of them can marry the lady, the knights do everything whithin their power to make life miserable for one another. This whole spectacle is watched by a very critical royal family. The knights really work their heads off to win the sympathy of the family. They will most certainly put in a good word for them with the princess.

Goal of the game:
The players are knights. The player who makes the biggest impression on the princess, can marry her and wins the game. Players collect points by fighting other knights (fighting), impressing family members of the princess with their spectacular horse riding shows (showing), riding faster that their opponents (trotting), winning a tournament and ofcourse by saving the princess.

The player characters in the game:
Sir Thanks-a-lot, Sir Chop-a-lot, Sir Robin Rudes prince of Dudes, Sir William Wimpy and the Dirty Duke of Dastardshire

This game is released at Essen 2007.

Spinjas is a ratcheted spinning top game created by Parker Brothers in the late 1980s. The game set was sold as a Battle Stadium plastic arena with two Power Winder launchers and two Spinja characters enclosed within the clam-shell designed arena. More characters, launchers, and an oversized playing arena were also made available separately. The objective of the game is to load your chosen character into the ratcheting launcher and each player would launch their top into the arena at the same time. The tops would ricochet off of each other until only one remained spinning or within the arena and that player was declared the winner.The tops are not customizable and are not associated with any other licensed properties.

Mind Twist is a 2-player game that has players racing to be the first to get to the top of a 3-D Board. On your turn, secretly select a number between 1 and 3. If your opponent doesn't challenge you, you reveal your secret number and move your piece closer to victory and then it's your opponent's turn. If your opponent challenges you, he or she tries to guess your secret number. If they get it right, you lose your turn and they now pick a number. If they get it wrong, you reveal your secret number and move that many spaces and take another turn.

item.description:
From Invisibile City Games:

"Area Shangzhou-Gold (64 new sectors!) just opened for development on CyberNet. Your corporation has obtained partially-exclusive initial development (and exploitation) rights to this potentially lucrative market. Your goal? Secure your company’s control over the area by either controlling all four Critical Nodes, laying exclusive claim to more than half of the sectors (33+), or accumulating enough Clout to pay off the regulating officials."

The game can be played with a chessboard, some tokens and tiles printed from Invisible City's website:

http://www.invisible-city.com/play/463/shangzhou-gold

The board consists of a 4x4 square grid of scoring positions with a point value of either 5, 10, or 15. Each scoring position contains a 5x5 grid of holes. So the overall interior grid of holes is 20x20. Around the edges of the board are 23 additional single holes which are scattered sparsely, with values from 25 to 75.

Each player gets a seesaw-like device with a hole in one end for placing his or her jacks. Players then 'snap' the other end of the device to fling the jack into the air and (one hopes) into a hole on the board. Jacks that do land in holes on the board score based on where they land.
Star Deck is a two player game of cards where you build your own starship with the cards provided in your own deck and then attack your enemy.

The game consists of 56 letter cards and play money. Cards are drawn one at a time, and placed for auction. The first player to successfully spell a word of four or more letters with his or her cards wins.

60 Major League Baseball logo and mascot cards are randomly placed face up on the board. Matches are made and removed from the game board. Pairs can be next to each other or many squares away as long as there are no other cards between the match. Player with the most pairs wins.

Designed for 4 year olds, the reversible, simple puzzle game board is assembled as a drainpipe. By rolling the die and using either colors or shapes, the winner is the first to get their spider to the top of the drainpipe.

item.description: Designed for ages 3 to 6, with no reading requirements. The object of the game is to build a path from the colored edge on one side of the bingo board to the same color on the other edge.

Players build caravan routes across the board—in the free lands near the wonderful lakes—vying to attain the most popular and lucrative caravan spots for their families. When all the lands have been filled with caravans, points are awarded for controlling lakes with gold coins and connected caravans groups. After a second round (which entails some minor changes), the player with the most points is crowned as the Gipsy King. Release: Essen 2007.

item.description:
The game box features a train going by a cowboy and horse as the cowboy waves.

The game has a spinner and the board features a green background with pink, dark green, yellow, and orange paths. The object of the game is to make money transporting passengers over a train route.

This is an old children's spin-and-move game. The cover features Tom carrying a pig running away from the butcher. There is a spinner and the board features red and blue line paths with small circles representing the places for the tokens to stop.
This game comes with 6 colored airplanes, dice, and various cards. The board has square spaces and several different colored tracks to advance on.

Players invade Great Britain from 250-1066 AD, winning petty kingdoms, attempting to build high kingdoms, crafting alliances with tribes of Britons and with later waves of invaders, all as they strive for supremacy. By game’s end, will they be able to establish themselves as the King of Scotland, the King of Wales or the King of England? Whoever claims the most valuable kingships throughout the course of history wins.

name.value: Care Bears Quest for Care-a-lot Card Game

item.description: The goal of the game is to lay down matching sets of Care Bear cards and be the player with the Care-a-Lot card at the end of the game.

Product Features:

+ 3 games in 1 scary head!

+ Grave Emergency, Scary Surgery and Creepy Check-Up games will leave you in stitches!

+ Scary monster phrases and sounds plus removeable head parts

+ Colours and style may vary

+ Requires 3 x AA batteries (not included)

+ Manufacturer's recommended age 5 years +

By Vivid Imaginations (in UK)

This game claims to be a " Fun Way to Learn Anatomy!" and is a "Chiropractic College Primer and NBCE Part 1 Board Review". Game is basically a "Trivial Pursuit" type game with hundreds of medical questions that would only be answerable by someone in a MEDICAL Field or Profession.
A game for small children in which players learn to know colors and make combinations of colors together with Winnie the Pooh and his friends. The first player to gather six colors wins the game.
A game played with colored dice. Players are mother mammoths going into the forest to take their babies back to home. The color of dice dictates which of the mamas goes forward.

This game uses a space exploration theme to teach players about number bases (binary, octal, decimal, etc.). Each player starts play with a "matrix card," a supply of plastic chips and a "flight sheet" for scoring. Gameplay consists of five flights, each containing two phases: "Blast Off" and "Establishing a Flight Path." After five flights have been completed, the player with the highest total score is declared the winner.

During the "Blast Off" phase, the player voted mission commander draws and announces cards from a special deck of playing cards containing the standard four suits but only the numbers 1 through 9 (Ace is replaced by 1, and no face cards are included). Players place chips on their matrix cards, Bingo-style, until every player has at least one complete row or column of chips. At this point, players choose from among the 3- and 4-digit numbers filled in on their cards to establish "flight numbers," which are written on their sheets.

In the "Establishing a Flight Path" phase, players are dealt cards from a second deck of "base cards." Some of these cards contain game-balancing bonuses and penalties which apply only when drawn by players holding specially-marked matrix cards. The remaining base cards list a planet of the solar system, the number base that the planet represents in the game, and a list of digits which are valid in the planet's base. For example, Mercury represents binary (base 2), so only digits 0 and 1 are allowed. The player replaces all illegal digits in his or her flight number with zeroes, then converts the resulting number to decimal using a special base conversion wheel included with the game (except for landings on Pluto, which already represents base 10 and requires no conversion). The final result is added to his or her score.

The game includes two sets of rules -- "Brief Instructions" which get players started in just two pages, and a 10-page "Guide Book" which includes more detailed instructions, game variations and mathematical background information. The game was filed as U.S. Patent 3,618,952.

Players have a chance to progress from one level of society to another by acquiring wealth through trading with other participants. Once the society is established, the group with the most wealth is given the right to make the rules for the game. The power group generally makes rules which maintain or increase its power and which those being governed consider to be unfair. This generally results in some sort of rebellion by the other members of the society.
Travel version of M.I.G. with 380 questions in five categories (Present & Past, Entertainment & Culture, Near & Far, Sports & Other, Nature & Science).

item.description:
Relive those exciting Cold War Conflicts!

A unique game developed to impart knowledge of Combat Engineer practices and procedures to US soldiers.

* Test your general and specific military knowledge against that of other combat engineers, for two to six MOS 12B or 12C at squad, platoon or company level.
 * Three folded sections of Game Board, with hex battlefield
 * Organization cards, 1 for Soviet, 1 for Engineer Company (2 sides)
 * 450 counters
 * 1 dice
 * 6 plastic card holders
 * set of small cardboard boxes to hold parts until you need them
 * 20 mission setup packets
 * 3.5" deck of cards
 o Mission Cards
 o Question/Answer Cards
 o Fortune of War cards

You are one of the initial businessmen helping to transform Atlantic City into the first real tourist destination in America. Invest in transportation and real estate (boarding houses and hotels) as you seek to capture more than your fair share of the dollars pouring in from the daytrippers and tourists coming from Philadelphia and New York. Muscle out your opponents, razing their boarding houses to put up your grand hotels. Can you become the real estate magnate of 19th century Atlantic City?

From the instruction page: This kit includes everything you need to play two fun math games. One game tests your addition skills. For the other game, subtraction skills are practiced.

Race your monster truck around and accross the game board as you solve the equations and win trophies!
